verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 22:4
verses.text: And this locality the Greeks were acquainted with by hearsay, and called it "Isles of the Blessed".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 22:5
verses.text: And there are other tenets of these which many of the Greeks have appropriated, and thus have from time to time formed their own opinions.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 22:6
verses.text: For the disciplinary system in regard of the Divinity, according to these (Jewish sects), is of greater antiquity than that of all nations.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 22:7
verses.text: And so it is that the proof is at hand, that all those (Greeks) who ventured to make assertions concerning God, or concerning the creation of existing things, derived their principles from no other source than from Jewish legislation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 22:8
verses.text: And among these may be particularized Pythagoras especially, and the Stoics, who derived (their systems) while resident among the Egyptians, by having become disciples of these Jews.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 22:9
verses.text: Now they affirm that there will be both a judgment and a conflagration of the universe, and that the wicked will be eternally punished.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 22:10
verses.text: And among them is cultivated the practice of prophecy, and the prediction of future events.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 23

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 23:1
verses.text: Another Sect of the Esseni: the Pharisees.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 23:2
verses.text: There is then another order of the Essenes who use the same customs and prescribed method of living with the foregoing sects, but make an alteration from these in one respect, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 23:3
verses.text: , marriage.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 23:4
verses.text: Now they maintain that those who have abrogated matrimony commit some terrible offence, which is for the destruction of life, and that they ought not to cut off the succession of children; for, that if all entertained this opinion, the entire race of men would easily be exterminated.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 23:5
verses.text: However, they make a trial of their betrothed women for a period of three years; and when they have been three times purified, with a view of proving their ability of bringing forth children, so then they wed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 23:6
verses.text: They do not, however, cohabit with pregnant women, evincing that they marry not from sensual motives, but from the advantage of children.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 23:7
verses.text: And the women likewise undergo ablution in a similar manner (with their husbands), and are themselves also arrayed in a linen garment, after the mode in which the men are with their girdles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 23:8
verses.text: These things, then, are the statements which I have to make respecting the Esseni.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 23:9
verses.text: But there are also others who themselves practise the Jewish customs; and these, both in respect of caste and in respect of the laws, are called Pharisees.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 23:10
verses.text: Now the greatest part of these is to be found in every locality, inasmuch as, though all are styled Jews, yet, on account of the peculiarity of the opinions advanced by them, they have been denominated by titles proper to each.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 23:11
verses.text: These, then, firmly hold the ancient tradition, and continue to pursue in a disputative spirit a close investigation into the things regarded according to the Law as clean and not clean.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 23:12
verses.text: And they interpret the regulations of the Law, and put forward teachers, whom they qualify for giving instruction in such things.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 23:13
verses.text: These Pharisees affirm the existence of fate, and that some things are in our power, whereas others are under the control of destiny.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 23:14
verses.text: In this way they maintain that some actions depend upon ourselves, whereas others upon fate.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 23:15
verses.text: But (they assert) that God is a cause of all things, and that nothing is managed or happens without His will.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 23:16
verses.text: These likewise acknowledge that there is a resurrection of flesh, and that soul is immortal, and that there will be a judgment and conflagration, and that the righteous will be imperishable, but that the wicked will endure everlasting punishment in unquenchable fire.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 24

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 24:1
verses.text: The Sadducees.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 24:2
verses.text: These, then, are the opinions even of the Pharisees.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 24:3
verses.text: The Sadducees, however, are for abolishing fate, and they acknowledge that God does nothing that is wicked, nor exercises providence over (earthly concerns); but they contend that the choice between good and evil lies within the power of men.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 24:4
verses.text: And they deny that there is a resurrection not only of flesh, but also they suppose that the soul does not continue after death.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 24:5
verses.text: The soul they consider nothing but mere vitality, and that it is on account of this that man has been created.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 24:6
verses.text: However, (they maintain) that the notion of the resurrection has been fully realized by the single circumstance, that we close our days after having left children upon earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 24:7
verses.text: But (they still insist) that after death one expects to suffer nothing, either bad or good; for that there will be a dissolution both of soul and body, and that man passes into non-existence, similarly also with the material of the animal creation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 24:8
verses.text: But as regards whatever wickedness a man may have committed in life, provided he may have been reconciled to the injured party, he has been a gainer (by transgression), inasmuch as he has escaped the punishment (that otherwise would have been inflicted) by men.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 24:9
verses.text: And whatever acquisitions a man may have made, and (in whatever respect), by becoming wealthy, he may have acquired distinction, he has so far been a gainer.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 24:10
verses.text: But (they abide by their assertion), that God has no solicitude about the concerns of an individual here.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 24:11
verses.text: And while the Pharisees are full of mutual affection, the Sadducees, on the other hand, are actuated by self-love.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 24:12
verses.text: This sect had its stronghold especially in the region around Samaria.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 24:13
verses.text: And these also adhere to the customs of the law, saying that one ought so to live, that he may conduct himself virtuously, and leave children behind him on earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 24:14
verses.text: They do not, however, devote attention to prophets, but neither do they to any other sages, except to the law of Moses only, in regard of which, however, they frame no interpretations.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 24:15
verses.text: These, then, are the opinions which also the Sadducees choose to teach.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 25

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 25:1
verses.text: The Jewish Religion.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 25:2
verses.text: Since, therefore, we have explained even the diversities among the Jews, it seems expedient likewise not to pass over in silence the system of their religion.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 25:3
verses.text: The doctrine, therefore, among all Jews on the subject of religion is fourfold-theological, natural, moral, and ceremonial.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 25:4
verses.text: And they affirm that there is one God, and that He is Creator and Lord of the universe: that He has formed all these glorious works which had no previous existence; and this, too, not out of any coeval substance that lay ready at hand, but His Willâ€”the efficient causeâ€”was to create, and He did create.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 25:5
verses.text: And (they maintain) that there are angels, and that these have been brought into being for ministering unto the creation; but also that there is a sovereign Spirit that always continues beside God, for glory and praise.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 25:6
verses.text: And that all things in the creation are endued with sensation, and that there is nothing inanimate.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 25:7
verses.text: And they earnestly aim at serious habits and a temperate life, as one may ascertain from their laws.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 25:8
verses.text: Now these matters have long ago been strictly defined by those who in ancient times have received the divinely-appointed law; so that the reader will find himself astonished at the amount of temperance, and of diligence, lavished on customs legally enacted in reference to man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 25:9
verses.text: The ceremonial service, however, which has been adapted to divine worship in a manner befitting the dignity of religion, has been practised amongst them with the highest degree of elaboration.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 25:10
verses.text: The superiority of their ritualism it is easy for those who wish it to ascertain, provided they read the book which furnishes information on these points.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 25:11
verses.text: They will thus perceive how that with solemnity and sanctity the Jewish priests offer unto God the first-fruits of the gifts bestowed by Him for the use and enjoyment of men; how they fulfil their ministrations with regularity and stedfastness, in obedience to His commandments.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 25:12
verses.text: There are, however, some (liturgical usages adopted) by these, which the Sadducees refuse to recognise, for they are not disposed to acquiesce in the existence of angels or spirits.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 25:13
verses.text: Still all parties alike expect Messiah, inasmuch as the Law certainly, and the prophets, preached beforehand that He was about to be present on earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 25:14
verses.text: Inasmuch, however, as the Jews were not cognizant of the period of His advent, there remains the supposition that the declarations (of Scripture) concerning His coming have not been fulfilled.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 25:15
verses.text: And so it is, that up to this day they continue in anticipation of the future coming of the Christ,â€”from the fact of their not discerning Him when He was present in the world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 25:16
verses.text: And (yet there can be little doubt but) that, on beholding the signs of the times of His having been already amongst us, the Jews are troubled; and that they are ashamed to confess that He has come, since they have with their own hands put Him to death, because they were stung with indignation in being convicted by Himself of not having obeyed the laws.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 25:17
verses.text: And they affirm that He who was thus sent forth by God is not this Christ (whom they are looking for); but they confess that another Messiah will come, who as yet has no existence; and that he will usher in some of the signs which the law and the prophets have shown beforehand, whereas, regarding the rest (of these indications), they suppose that they have fallen into error.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 25:18
verses.text: For they say that his generation will be from the stock of David, but not from a virgin and the Holy Spirit, but from a woman and a man, according as it is a rule for all to be procreated from seed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 25:19
verses.text: And they allege that this Messiah will be King over them,â€”a warlike and powerful individual, who, after having gathered together the entire people of the Jews, and having done battle with all the nations, will restore for them Jerusalem the royal city.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 25:20
verses.text: And into this city He will collect together the entire Hebrew race, and bring it back once more into the ancient customs, that it may fulfil the regal and sacerdotal functions, and dwell in confidence for periods of time of sufficient duration.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 25:21
verses.text: After this repose, it is their opinion that war would next be waged against them after being thus congregated; that in this conflict Christ would fall by the edge of the sword; and that, after no long time, would next succeed the termination and conflagration of the universe; and that in this way their opinions concerning the resurrection would receive completion, and a recompense be rendered to each man according to his works.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 26

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 26:1
verses.text: Conclusion to the Work Explained.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 26:2
verses.text: It now seems to us that the tenets of both all the Greeks and barbarians have been sufficiently explained by us, and that nothing has remained unrefuted either of the points about which philosophy has been busied, or of the allegations advanced by the heretics.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 26:3
verses.text: And from these very explanations the condemnation of the heretics is obvious, for having either purloined their doctrines, or derived contributions to them from some of those tenets elaborately worked out by the Greeks, and for having advanced (these opinions) as if they originated from God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 26:4
verses.text: Since, therefore, we have hurriedly passed through all the systems of these, and with much labour have, in the nine books, proclaimed all their opinions, and have left behind us for all men a small viaticum in life, and to those who are our contemporaries have afforded a desire of learning (with) great joy and delight, we have considered it reasonable, as a crowning stroke to the entire work, to introduce the discourse (already mentioned) concerning the truth, and to furnish our delineation of this in one book, namely the tenth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies VIII 26:5
verses.text: Our object is, that the reader, not only when made acquainted with the overthrow of those who have presumed to establish heresies, may regard with scorn their idle fancies, but also, when brought to know the power of the truth, may be placed in the way of salvation, by reposing that faith in God which He so worthily deserves.
